stem: A 24-year-old client with a known Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) and a recent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) suddenly develops left-sided weakness and facial droop. Based on the documentation in the Critical Cardio-Neurology & Bubble Study Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute ischemic stroke in a young patient with venous history.
Background: DVT in right leg following leg surgery. Known PFO (Congenital).
Assessment: NIHSS score of 12. Droop and hemiparesis.
Recommendation: Bubble Echo and stabilization.

conditionOptions.text: Paradoxical Embolism (Venous Clot crossing to Arterial)
Simple Pulmonary Embolism (Venous to Lung only)

actionOptions.text: Prepare for emergent mechanical thrombectomy or thrombolytic therapy
Initiate IV Heparin as prescribed to prevent further embolization
Instruct the client to perform a Valsalva maneuver to stop the shunting
Administer STAT IV Calcium to strengthen the heart valve

parameterOptions.text: Neurological status (NIHSS Score) and motor function
Respiratory status and SpO2 (Monitoring for concurrent PE)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a Paradoxical Embolism (c2). In a patient with a Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO), a venous clot (DVT) can bypass the lungs by crossing from the right atrium to the left atrium. Once in the left side of the heart, it enters the systemic arterial circulation and can travel to the brain (Stroke). The 'Bubble Study' (showing bubbles crossing sides) confirms the shunt. Priority actions involve managing the stroke (a1) and preventing more clots with Heparin (a2). Monitoring focuses on neuro-recovery (p1) and pulmonary stability (p2).
clinicalPearls: Paradoxical embolism is the primary cause of 'Cryptogenic' (mystery) strokes in young people.
A 'Bubble Study' uses agitated saline to create micro-bubbles that are tracked via Echo; if they cross the heart wall, the PFO is open.
PE and Stroke can happen simultaneously in these patients.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a DVT can *only* go to the lungs.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Normally, yes. But if the question mentions a 'PFO' or an 'Atrial Septal Defect (ASD),' the clot can jump the fence into the brain. In the NCLEX world, PFO + DVT + Stroke = Paradoxical Embolism.

mnemonic.title: Clot-Jump
mnemonic.expansion: C-Crossing over. L-Leg DVT is the source. O-Open hole (PFO). T-Travels to Brain (Stroke).
